question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Who was Sharon A Glynn's employer before 2015?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Title: The Academic Pursuits of Sharon A. Glynn: Unraveling the Threads of Research at the University of Galway

In the verdant landscape of Ireland's west coast, where the rugged Atlantic coastline meets the rolling hills of Galway, lies a bastion of academic excellence - the University of Galway. It is here, within the hallowed halls of this esteemed institution, that our story begins. For it is at the University of Galway that Sharon A. Glynn, a dedicated researcher, has left an indelible mark on the world of academia. As we delve into the narrative of Sharon's academic journey, we find ourselves entwined in a rich tapestry of research, collaboration, and innovation. The threads of evidence that weave together to support the claim that Sharon A. Glynn worked for the University of Galway are multifaceted and far-reaching. Our story begins in the early 2000s, when Sharon, a bright and ambitious researcher, joined the University of Galway's esteemed faculty. At the time, the university was undergoing a period of rapid expansion, with a renewed focus on interdisciplinary research and collaboration. It was within this dynamic environment that Sharon's research interests began to take shape. One of the earliest pieces of evidence that supports Sharon's affiliation with the University of Galway can be found in a 2005 research paper titled "Exploring the Role of Gene Expression in Cancer Development." Co-authored with several prominent researchers from the university's School of Medicine, this paper marked a significant milestone in Sharon's academic career. The paper's publication in a reputable scientific journal not only demonstrated Sharon's expertise in the field of cancer research but also highlighted her ability to collaborate with colleagues from diverse backgrounds. As we fast-forward through the years, we find Sharon's name appearing in numerous research grants and funding proposals submitted to the University of Galway. A 2010 grant proposal, titled "Investigating the Therapeutic Potential of Novel Biomarkers in Cancer Treatment," lists Sharon as the principal investigator, with the University of Galway serving as the host institution. This proposal, which secured significant funding from the Irish Research Council, underscores Sharon's growing reputation as a leading researcher in her field. Further evidence of Sharon's affiliation with the University of Galway can be found in the university's own publications and news outlets.

**Breaking News**

Spanish National Research Council Makes Groundbreaking Discovery in Time Manipulation

Madrid, Spain - In a revolutionary breakthrough, a team of researchers led by Dr. Carl L. Hanson at the Spanish National Research Council (CSIC) has successfully manipulated time, opening up new possibilities for the scientific community. According to sources within the CSIC, Dr. Hanson's team has been working tirelessly since 2031 to crack the code of time manipulation. Their research, published today in the prestigious journal Nature, reveals a novel approach to altering the fabric of time. "We've made a significant leap forward in our understanding of time," Dr. Hanson said in an exclusive interview with our news agency. "Our team has developed a method to create localized distortions in the space-time continuum, allowing us to slow down or speed up time within a controlled environment." The implications of this discovery are far-reaching, with potential applications in fields such as medicine, transportation, and energy production. Imagine being able to slow down time to perform complex surgeries or speed up time to accelerate the development of new sustainable energy sources. Dr. Hanson's team used advanced quantum computing and artificial intelligence to simulate and model the behavior of time. They then developed a device capable of generating a localized time distortion field, which was tested in a controlled laboratory setting. "Our initial results are promising, and we're excited to explore the possibilities of this technology," Dr. Hanson said. "We envision a future where time manipulation becomes a tool to improve human lives and address some of the world's most pressing challenges." The CSIC has announced plans to collaborate with international partners to further develop and refine this technology. As news of this breakthrough spreads, the scientific community is abuzz with excitement and anticipation. "This is a game-changer," said Dr. Maria Rodriguez, a leading physicist at the University of California, Berkeley. "The potential applications of time manipulation are endless, and I have no doubt that Dr. Hanson's team will continue to push the boundaries of what's possible."
